name: methyl_propyl_sulfide
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: 1,3-propanedithiol has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for our comparison will be ethanedithiol, which has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of one additional phenyl group. Phenyl groups, when connected to a propanedithiol base, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of methyl_propyl_sulfide, we have one additional phenyl group linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
